theory: Usopp vs. Perona parallels Luffy vs. Enel - Natural Counter Theory
author: Multiple One Piece fans
evidence: Usopp's naturally negative personality makes him immune to Perona's Negative Hollow attacks
Similar to how Luffy's rubber body made him immune to Enel's lightning
Both victories rely on an inherent character trait rather than training or power-ups
Oda consistently creates matchups where specific character traits counter seemingly invincible opponents
communityReception: Widely accepted by the fandom as intentional parallel storytelling by Oda. Praised as genius character matchmaking.

theory: Perona's Negative Hollow Trauma Theory - Long-lasting Effects on Luffy
author: FandomWire contributor
evidence: During the Egghead Island arc, Luffy encounters similar holograms and calls them 'Hollow-Hollow' (Perona's fruit name)
Luffy's reaction suggests he remembers the traumatic experience with Perona's ghosts
This demonstrates continuity in Luffy's character memories and experiences
counterArguments: Could be coincidental terminology rather than trauma reference
Luffy typically doesn't hold onto negative experiences for extended periods
communityReception: Mixed reception. Some fans find it compelling evidence of character continuity, others think it's reading too much into dialogue.

theory: Usopp's Lies Becoming Reality - Fake Weapons Theory
author: One Piece community
evidence: Usopp defeats Perona entirely with fake weapons - toy cockroaches and an inflatable hammer
This continues the series theme that Usopp's lies and bluffs often become more powerful than reality
The episode title emphasizes the 'U' in 'Uso' (lie) being the same as in 'Usopp'
Demonstrates that in One Piece, belief and perception can be more powerful than physical reality
communityReception: Widely accepted as thematic analysis. Fans appreciate how Oda uses Usopp's character to explore themes of truth, lies, and perception in battle.

theory: Perona's Defeat Foreshadows Her Character Development
author: Thriller Bark analysis community
source: Various One Piece forums and wiki discussions
evidence: Perona's defeat through fear and vulnerability humanizes her character
Her fear of cockroaches makes her relatable despite her ghost powers
This defeat sets up her later character arc and eventual alliance with certain characters
counterArguments: At the time of this episode, future character development wasn't yet written
communityReception: Retrospective appreciation. Fans looking back see this as the beginning of Perona becoming a more complex, sympathetic character rather than just a villain.
